fn.p: Roberto Dell’Anno is a professor in the Department of Economic, Business, Legal, Commodity and Geographical Sciences at University of Foggia (Italy). He received his doctorate in public economics from University of Salerno (Italy). Much of his research has examined the methods to estimate the shadow economy. He has also worked on transition countries and behavioral economics.

Paulo Mourao is a professor (PhD Assistant) in the Department of Economics at University of Minho (Portugal). He received his doctorate in economics from University of Minho. His research is focused in public finances, namely, fiscal illusion and public expenditures. He has also researched social economics and sports economics.

abstract.p: This article estimates the magnitude of fiscal illusion around the world and evaluates whether relationships exist between fiscal illusion and a set of potential observed variables. The index of fiscal illusion is derived for approximately fifty countries over the period 2000–08. Using MIMIC models, the authors conclude that the structure of employment (self-employment as a percentage of total employment) and nominal marginal tax rates, by increasing the visibility of the tax burden, may constitute the greatest incentives for policy makers to distort taxpayers' perceptions. Less relevant are the determinants of fiscal illusion related to the information acquisition and processing capabilities of the taxpayer (i.e., freedom of the press and tertiary education).

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Fiscal illusion occurs every time a taxpayer does not realize how much he pays to the state or how much he receives from the state. This phenomenon is ubiquitous and has been studied since the beginning of the twentieth century. Some attempts have recently been made to measure the level of fiscal illusion for certain sample countries.

The study of fiscal illusion is important because this concept is a source of distrust between the state and its citizens. According to Amilcare Puviani, the father of the economic study of fiscal illusion, this double “ignorance” can lead to a fiscal delusion that can harm democratic life.

In this study, we analyze fiscal illusion using the Multiple Indicators and Multiple Causes (MIMIC) approach. In addition, we test the relationship of fiscal illusion with the main causes and indicators detailed in the literature.

The MIMIC approach is applied to analyze fiscal illusion as a latent variable. It allows us to think of this model as comprising two parts: a structural equation for fiscal illusion that relates the latent variable to the causes and a system of measurement equations that takes into account that there are several indicators of this unobserved phenomenon.

For each of the determinants chosen to represent the latent construct, a weight (factor loading) is estimated. This weight represents how much a specific cause counts in explaining fiscal illusion with reference to the other observed causes. On the basis of these parameters, an index of the magnitude of fiscal illusion for forty-seven countries across the period 2000–08 is proposed.

A preliminary consideration may be useful in interpreting the insights of the empirical model. The latent variable approach proposed in this article does not mean that, in the mind of citizens, there exists an objective vision of the economic process but that it is obfuscated by “errors” of perception (i.e., fiscal illusion). If this circumstance were so, the implication would be that once the latent variable (fiscal illusion) is “revealed,” then the relationship between tax authorities and citizens becomes objectively measurable. Following the concept in Buchanan (1967), the “fiscal illusions” are not regarded as “errors” of the citizens. Rather, they are explanatory of a phenomenon whereby the policy maker alters the perceptions of taxpayers deliberately, and, through this process, directs the bias in individual fiscal choice. In this sense, our approach for estimating the fiscal illusion holds to Buchanan and Wagner’s (2000, 133) hypothesis that “fiscal illusions” genuinely depend on the “nonobjectifiable elements of preference.”

The outline of the article is as follows. What Do We Know about Fiscal Illusion? section provides an overview of the literature concerning the role of fiscal illusion, with particular references to empirical studies. An Analysis of Fiscal Illusion by the Structural Equation Model section is structured into three subsections and describes the empirical analysis. The first subsection illustrates the econometric approach of structural equation modeling (SEM); Causes and Indicators of Fiscal Illusion subsection discusses the main causes and indicators of fiscal illusion; and the third subsection explicates the procedure to calculate the index of fiscal illusion and reports the index scores of various countries. The study ends with policy implications and general conclusions.

sec.title: What Do We Know about Fiscal Illusion?
sec.p: The identification of the first references to fiscal illusion in economic literature is difficult. Although the term “fiscal illusion” had not been specifically used, some authors (e.g., Colbert as cited in Stiglitz 1999) before the nineteenth century had discussed different ways of deceiving taxpayers using appropriate tax strategies.

In the nineteenth century, Ricardo (1820) discussed the varying visibility of funding for state programs, accomplished by using budget deficits with respect to public debt. Years later, Mill ([1848] 1994) discussed the visibility of different taxes in the following statement: “If all taxes were direct, taxation would be much more perceived than at present, and there would be a security, which now there is not, for economy in the public expenditure.”

Despite these earlier ambiguous references, Puviani (1903) first introduced the term “fiscal illusion.” Puviani (1903) and later Fasiani (1941) were worried about the omnipresence and omniscience of the state within citizens' lives. As Von Hayek (1944) discussed, an enlarged state will tend to diminish citizens' rights, and, as a monopolistic supplier of goods and services, it will tend to be inefficient. Moreover, this kind of monopolistic state (Fasiani 1941) will use various strategies to deceive taxpayers.

Buchanan (1967) detailed these strategies and introduced the issue to the mainstream study of economics; furthermore, his work sparked other works that deepened the study of fiscal illusion (Oates 1988). In this framework, Twight (1994) also studied the budgetary strategies that may increase fiscal illusion: biased macroeconomic forecasts, biased estimates of the effects of policy changes on budgetary outcomes, strategic use of on- and off-budget expenditures and receipts, manipulation of budgetary baselines, and multiyear budgeting (Lipford 2001; Mourao 2008).

This theme of fiscal illusion study emerged again in the first decade of the twenty-first century with Sausgruber and Tyran (2005), Eusepi (2006), and Mourao (2007, 2008). In spite of the time separation of their works, all of these authors recognize several common characteristics. First, fiscal illusion is a political illusion (Puviani 1903; Fasiani 1941). A political illusion occurs when politicians deceive citizens by denying or obscuring the social reality that these rulers know is actually happening. If politicians use fiscal instruments to deceive taxpayers, then political illusions are essentially fiscal illusions.

Second, fiscal illusion is caused by economic, social, and political facts, the most important of which are the nature of less assertive taxpayers (Fasiani 1941), the opacity of taxation (Mill [1848] 1994; Puviani 1903), the taxation strategies (Buchanan 1967), and the education level of the population (Mourao 2008). Third, fiscal illusion has serious consequences, such as an increase in the public debt (Puviani 1903), a deterioration in long-term public balances (Buchanan and Wagner 2000), the preference for indirect taxation (Mill [1848] 1994), and tax fragmentation (Sausgruber and Tyran 2005). Keefer and Knack (1997) and Eusepi (2006) also agree that fiscal illusion leads to budget deterioration, which happens more often in contexts of low institutional quality. In these cases, they follow Fasiani (1941), who argued that fiscal illusion belongs to the group of optimistic political illusions. With optimistic political illusions, taxpayers feel that they are paying less than they are really paying. They also tend to attribute more value to public expenditures than these outlays really deserve. Winter and Mouritzen (2001) and Sanandaji and Wallace (2003) likewise argue that voters tend to follow a public hedonic editing and that they actually prefer not be reminded of the costs of public programs.

Dollery and Worthington (1996) conducted a survey of the empirical literature on fiscal illusion that developed until the 1990s. In their survey, they observe that there are five main directions taken by the empirical literature1: (1) studies on tax revenues' complexity; (2) studies on revenues' elasticity; (3) studies on the flypaper effect; (4) studies on rent illusion; and (5) studies on debt illusion.

The first direction (“studies on tax revenues' complexity”) argues that a more complex tax system helps the government increase public expenditures without the full perception of taxpayers (Wagner 1976; Cullis and Jones 1987; Heyndels and Smolders 1995; Dollery and Worthington 1999a).

The second direction (“studies on revenues' elasticity”) claims that higher levels of revenues-income elasticity ease the collection of “automatic” revenues and, thereby, accelerate the political approval of the sustainability of more expenditures (Greene and Hawley 1991; Heyndels and Smolders 1994; Dollery and Worthington 1995a).

The “studies on the flypaper effect” test the hypothesis that lump-sum grants increase public outlays more than other sources of budget maximization. It is one of the most relevant (and controversial) strands of the literature on fiscal illusion.2 According to Aragon (2008), most explanations focus on identifying flaws in the empirical strategy, such as omitted variables (Hamilton 1983), mistakes in classifying conditional transfers as lump-sum grants (Moffitt 1984), functional misspecification (Becker 1996), and reverse causality (Knight 2002). For a detailed survey of the literature, see Wycoff (1991), Heyndels and Smolders (1994), Hines and Thaler (1995), Dollery and Worthington (1995a), and Inman (2008).

The fourth direction (“studies on rent illusion”) observes that as the number of renters increases in a certain place, it becomes more expected that public expenditures will also tend to rise. This trend is because expenditures profit all citizens, but costs tend to be supported by few, mainly the voters charged by property taxes. Among the empirical studies on renter illusion are Heyndels and Smolders (1994), Carroll and Yinger (1994), Worthington (1994), and Gemmell, Morrissey, and Pinar (2002).

The fifth direction (“studies on debt illusion”) recognizes that current taxation generates higher levels of perception by voters–taxpayers than public indebtedness. Dollery and Worthington (1995b) analyze four empirical studies in this area: Oates (1969), Epple and Schipper (1981), and Dalamagas (1992, 1993).

However, new directions have been developed in empirical works on fiscal illusion, which explore the borders between psychology and economics. In this strand of literature, particularly influential is the Hines and Thaler (1995) explanation of a specific type of fiscal illusion (the flypaper effect) as the product of behavioral phenomena. According to Hines and Thaler (1995), loss aversion and a lack of fungibility (Kahneman, Knetsch, and Thaler 1991; Thaler 1990) are behind the flypaper effect.3 New directions have also been developed from a methodological point of view and involve experimental analysis of fiscal illusion (Sausgruber and Tyran 2005).

In this article, we follow this interdisciplinary perspective by proposing a statistical methodology (i.e., SEM) that is widely used by researchers in the social and behavioral sciences. In these disciplines, the SEM is utilized to analyze latent (unobservable) variables such as attitudes, perceptions, and intelligence quotient scores. To our knowledge, this article is the first empirical attempt to discuss macroeconomic fiscal illusion as a latent dimension. The next section details the methodological steps.

sec.title: An Analysis of Fiscal Illusion by the Structural Equation Model
sec.p: In this section, we attempt to find some plausible answers to the main questions raised in the literature on fiscal illusion. In particular, a confirmatory analysis responds to the following questions: What are the main causes and indicators of fiscal illusion? What is the magnitude of fiscal illusion in the past decade around the world?

To find the answers to these queries, the “ad hoc” econometric model, namely, a MIMIC model is applied, which is a special case of the more general SEM. The SEM is widely used in marketing and psychometric literature to model relationships between unobserved constructs and manifest variables and to control for measurement error. According to the main literature, the SEM should be used as a confirmatory (based on a theoretical rationale), and not as an exploratory, method (Bullock, Harlow, and Mulaik, 1994; Hair et al. 1998). In this sense, we wish to test whether the loadings of the measured variables (indicators and causes) confirm the underlying theory of fiscal illusion.

sec.title: The SEM and the MIMIC Approach
sec.p: Structural equation models are based on statistical relationships among latent (unobserved) and manifest (observed) variables. The SEM is an extension of the general linear model that simultaneously estimates relationships between multiple independent, dependent, and latent variables. In this sense, the SEM includes path analysis and multivariate regression as special cases. According to the Organization for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD 2008), this approach is particularly useful when working with composite indicators, given that, in most cases, the available indicators only imperfectly measure theoretical concepts.

For this research, a special case of the SEM is considered: the MIMIC model. The MIMIC model received its name from Jöreskog and Goldberger (1975). It was introduced to economics by Weck-Hannemann (1983), and it has usually been applied to the analyses of shadow economies.4 To the best of our knowledge, our study presents the first application of the SEM to the issue of fiscal illusion.

sec.title: Causes and Indicators of Fiscal Illusion
sec.p: In this subsection, the theoretical background behind the MIMIC model is explained. According to Duncan (1975), it is a key issue for this approach because the meaning of the latent variable, and, hence, the reliability of the estimates of the fiscal illusion index, depend completely on how correctly and comprehensively the causal and indicator variables correspond to the intended content of the latent variable.

The aim of this research is to include, among the causes, those variables that make it easier for a policy maker to exploit, with greater likelihood, fiscal illusion mechanisms to distort taxpayers' perceptions of their tax burdens. Moreover, we include as indicators of the latent variable the proxies that can account for the most common strategies to reduce citizens' perceptions of their tax burdens.

In particular, we choose four indicators of fiscal illusion. The first one is the public debt as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP). The relevance of this variable is stressed by the study of Puviani (1903). He considers public debt to be a fundamental institution of fiscal illusion (Buchanan 1967). According to Puviani’s view, individual taxpayers do not act as expected by the basic Ricardian equivalence proposition.9

The second indicator is the public budget balance. Regarding this proxy, Buchanan and Wagner (2000) assert that high public deficits reduce the perceived tax burden to the current generation of taxpayers. As Christopoulos and Tsionas (2003) point out, utilization of the public budget balance has been considered one of the most effective strategies to increase the expenditure dimension of fiscal illusion. The relevance of this relationship between budget deficits and government spending is supported by several empirical studies (Niskanen 1978; Ashworth 1995; Hondroyiannis and Papapetrou 2001). In line with these studies, Christopoulos and Tsionas (2003) also find empirical evidence that high public deficits reduce the perceived price of public goods (increasing fiscal illusion). According to our data set, this variable explains the greater part of the variability of the latent factor (R 2 approximately 80 percent), and hence it is chosen as the “reference variable.” As previously mentioned, when using the MIMIC approach, we need to fix a scale variable to estimate the remaining parameters as a function of this scale variable. The value of the fixed parameter is arbitrary, but by using a positive (or negative) unit value, it is easier to establish the relative magnitude of the other indicator variables. According to well-established empirical literature, we fix a negative unit value for the coefficient of scale (λ2).10

The third indicator of fiscal illusion is the ratio between indirect and direct tax revenues. In literature, this hypothesis is also known as Mill’s hypothesis. According to Mill (1848), the tax burden from indirect taxation is underestimated because indirect taxes are less “visible” than direct taxes (Sausgruber and Tyran 2005). For Buchanan (1967), this type of illusion arises because the tax is actually absorbed in the payment that an individual makes for private goods and services. This type of tax is characteristic of specific excise taxes, where the tax is nominally included in the price of a private good or service but is relevant for each form of indirect taxation. In the literature on fiscal illusion, it is well established that increasing the share of revenue collected by indirect taxes is indicative of a greater exploitation of fiscal-illusion strategies by the policy maker (Pommerehne and Schneider 1978; Dollery and Worthington 1999b). Thus, the empirical test of Mill’s hypothesis consists of finding evidence that an increase in the ratio between the revenues from indirect and direct taxes leads to a higher index of fiscal illusion. According to our view, a positive coefficient is expected between the latent variable and y 3.

The fourth indicator of fiscal illusion is the Hirschman–Herfindahl concentration index (H) of tax revenue. The H index is usually applied as a measure of the complexity or fragmentation of the tax structure. The fragmentation of the tax system can be defined as the extent to which total tax revenue is dispersed over different taxes. It is seen as the first determinant of the complexity of a given tax system. Buchanan and Wagner (2000) argue that complex payment structures (together with indirect taxation) create a fiscal illusion that induces underestimation of the tax prices of public expenditures. According to this hypothesis, the more complicated the revenue system, the more difficult it is for the taxpayer to determine the “tax price” of public outputs and the more likely it is that he will underestimate the tax burden associated with public programs. Wagner (1976) was the first to use the Hirschman–Herfindahl concentration index to examine fiscal illusion. As Oates (1988) points out, Wagner’s choice has been an influential one because every subsequent study of the revenue-complexity hypothesis has used this index as the measure of the illusion variable. In this case, a higher value of the H index is associated with a less complex revenue system. Therefore, the revenue-fragmentation hypothesis posits a negative coefficient for the parameter λ4.

Regarding the causes of fiscal illusion, we include some variables that characterize the socioeconomic aspects of a country. In contrast to the indicators of the latent variable, these causes are not directly connected to the policy maker’s strategies to distort the taxpayer’s perception of his tax burden.

The first cause is the ratio between self-employed workers and the total employed population. Following the method of Fasiani (1941), ceteris paribus, the higher the ratio, the more visible the tax burden because more “active” tax compliance is required for these workers than for employees. This result occurs because, for the self-employed, the system of withholding income tax is rather partial. In our view, a higher self-employment rate is expected to raise the index of fiscal illusion because it increases the policy maker’s incentives to distort the perception of the tax burden.

The next two observed causes are related to both the size (tax burden) and the structure (marginal tax) of the tax system (Buchanan 1967). Although they play a relevant role in fiscal illusion, the effects of these variables may be ambiguous. For instance, the tax burden may be considered a proxy for the policy maker’s need to reduce the perception of tax pressure. Thus, from one side, a higher (effective) tax burden encourages a government to adopt tax policies aimed at increasing fiscal illusion. Alternatively, when the tax burden is high, the citizens may become accustomed to a weighty taxation regime. Therefore, their disagreement with more burdensome taxation may be weak. In this case, overindulgent citizens may provide disincentives for the policy maker to carry out fiscal illusion strategies.

The third potential cause of fiscal illusion is related to misperception of tax rates.12 This illusion is accounted for by the index of top marginal income and payroll tax rates, published by the Index of Economic Freedom. According to Buchanan (1967) and Buchanan and Wagner (2000), there is an observed tendency of taxpayers to think in terms of marginal rates instead of average tax rates. This illusion means that the higher the top marginal income tax rate, the more visible the perception of tax burden. According to these hypotheses, the higher the total tax receipt (as a percentage of GDP) and, especially, the top marginal income tax rate, the higher the incentive should be to carry out fiscal illusion strategies. In this sense, positive coefficients are expected for both of the tax variables β2 and β3.

The fourth and fifth potential causes of the latent variable are related to the nonmonetary factors that may affect the perception of fiscal illusion (Mourao 2008). They are the overall index of freedom of the press and one of its subindices, the political pressures and controls on media content, as published by Freedom House.13 The inclusion of these two variables among the determinants of fiscal illusion is designed to take into account the effective chance of citizens not getting distorted information about expenditure and tax revenue policies. It seems intuitively reasonable that the greater the freedom of the media (lower index score), the lower the fiscal illusion should be. It becomes a harder task for a policy maker to distort the perception of the tax burden if the media supports individuals in discovering fiscal illusion strategies. According to this view, both the coefficients β4 and β5 are expected to be positive.

The final potential cause of fiscal illusion takes into account the ability of a society to correctly evaluate beneficiaries of both tax reforms and public expenditure programs. In assuming that this ability can be inferred from the education level of the whole society, we consider the percentage of people in the total population completing higher (tertiary) school. It is assumed that higher education reduces the effectiveness of the fiscal illusion mechanisms applied to distort citizens' perception of their tax burdens. Thus, a negative correlation between x6 and the index of fiscal illusion is expected.

sec.p: The most general specification of the model is MIMIC 6-1-4 (six determinants, one latent variable, and four indicators—with and without intercept). Table 2 reports the maximum likelihood estimation of the MIMIC models, as implemented in Lisrel 8.54. According to the chi-square test of good fit, the hypothesis that the models are correct would be rejected. However, this finding should be evaluated very cautiously because the chi-square test has a statistical validity only if there are large samples and multinormal distributions (Kline 2005). In our data set, multivariate normality does not hold. Given these circumstances, a more reliable test of close fit, based on the root mean square error of approximation (RMSEA), can be considered. This test is regarded as relatively independent of sample size and, additionally, favors parsimonious models (Browne and Cudeck 1993). According to this test, we conclude that, with the exclusion of MIMIC 6-1-4 (with means) and MIMIC 4-1-3, all the models show a good fit according to RMSEA. sec.p: With reference to the estimated coefficients, we find that all the measurement loadings are statistically significant and have, for most of the variables, the expected signs. This result confirms the theoretical literature with regard to the most common strategies for distorting the taxpayer’s perception of his tax burden.

Looking at the structural equation, we find unambiguous empirical validation of the causes of fiscal illusion that directly influence tax compliance: the self-employment ratio and the top marginal tax rate. In contrast, the empirical findings for variables that account for nonmonetary (institutional) determinants of fiscal illusion remain ambiguous. In particular, we cannot reject the null hypothesis that the freedom of the press (x 4) is uncorrelated with the index of fiscal illusion and that, with reference to the proxy for political control of the media (x 5), it has an unexpected negative effect on fiscal illusion. With respect to the percentage of higher (tertiary) school-educated people in the population (x 6), an expected negative correlation with the latent variable is estimated.15

sec.p: Due to several missing values, the index of fiscal illusion, based on the country average, is regarded as more reliable than an index of annual changes. Figure 1 shows the ranking of countries according to fiscal illusion. From this analysis, we find evidence that Latin American policy makers exploit greater fiscal illusion stratagems to distort taxpayers' perceptions of their tax burdens than do policy makers in other regions of the world. In contrast, European countries show the lowest values among the estimated indices of fiscal illusion.

sec.p: These results are in line with those achieved by Mourao (2008), who developed the first index for fiscal illusion. Beginning in 1960, he studied sixty-eight countries, using Multi-Way Principal Components Analysis. Although he did not disaggregate the countries by continents as we have, Mourao (2008) found that the levels of fiscal illusion were more apparent for developing countries than for developed countries and that the levels of fiscal illusion tended to decline in the long term. Our index of fiscal illusion has a Spearman correlation of .428 with Mourao’s (2008) index of fiscal illusion, which allows us to reject the null hypothesis of the independence of the two indices (full results are available upon request).

Finally, we propose to determine whether the degree of political and fiscal decentralization is correlated with the size of fiscal illusion. There is an extensive literature on the link between fiscal illusion and decentralization (Grossman 1990; Dollery and Worthington 1995b, 1999b; Mitias and Turnbull 2001). The rationale behind this perceived relationship is that the separation of taxing and spending powers distorts local taxpayers' judgment of the true costs and benefits of public expenditures. This perception implies that decentralization may increase tax revenues' complexity, reduce the ability of voters to assign political responsibility for fiscal policy, or cause the flypaper effect. At the very least, building a structured database to assess the various fiscal, political, and administrative dimensions of decentralization in countries on a comparative worldwide basis is a challenging issue. Beck et al. sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This article synthesizes the theories regarding fiscal illusion determinants and takes the examination further by estimating the magnitude of fiscal illusion across forty-seven countries around the world. The empirical analysis has been carried out using a new methodology for this issue: SEM. A special case of SEM—the MIMIC model—is considered to analyze fiscal illusion as a latent variable.

This article empirically assesses the main hypotheses suggested in the literature regarding the causes and indicators of fiscal illusion. The results show that higher levels of fiscal illusion are positively correlated both with the public debt level and with the ratio of indirect taxes to direct taxes. The results also indicate that the more complicated the revenue system, the greater the fiscal illusion. Regarding the causes of fiscal illusion, the structure of employment (measured by the ratio of self-employment to total employment) and the nominal (marginal) tax rates, by increasing the visibility of the tax burden, underlie the greatest incentives for the policy maker to distort taxpayers' perceptions.

Less relevant are the determinants of fiscal illusion related to the information acquisition and processing capabilities of the taxpayer. The null hypothesis that the indices of the freedom of the press and fiscal illusion are uncorrelated cannot be rejected. Likewise, there is no robust, statistically significant relationship between fiscal illusion and tertiary education. With reference to the proxy for political control of the media, it has an unexpected negative effect on fiscal illusion.

We also check for the difference in size of fiscal illusion between federal and unitary forms of government. According to our findings, the hypothesis that the degree of decentralization is correlated with the size of fiscal illusion is not supported. Comparative analysis based on the estimated index of fiscal illusion around the world reveals that fiscal illusion is more severe, on average, in Latin American, Asian, and African democracies than in North American or European countries.

These results inspire us to highlight some implications for political economy and public finances. First, an overall improvement in free circulation of information is ineffective in reducing fiscal illusion. Very specialized skills would be required by citizens and journalists to recognize pro-fiscal illusion strategies. We infer that information asymmetry cannot be effectively discovered by taxpayers only through free media. In this sense, fiscal illusion remains an issue relegated to a place outside the public domain and political debate. The predominance of technical aspects partially deprives citizens of their democratic control over their government’s fiscal policy. This situation means lower resistance against fiscal illusion strategies, lack of significant voter pressure on the political parties, and, consequently, greater effective tax burdens and size of the public sector.

Second, fiscal illusion is mainly generated by fiscal issues. Therefore, to diminish fiscal illusion and consequently diminish the probability of fiscal delusion crises as warned by Fasiani (1941), we must work for clearer legislative packages at national levels that will promote the reconciliation of public finance reports around the world and stimulate more assertive taxpayers. Better public administration practices have to be implemented, for example, a move to increase the transparency level of public reports and initiatives to bring about an improvement in the participation level of citizens in public decisions to allow them to be the best guardians of the budgetary process.
